Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Interactive Multi-Touch Collaborative Table for Classrooms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II award proposes to develop a multi-touch table with object tracking and smart surface devices to create a highly versatile augmented-reality lab bench. The resulting instrument allows collaborative experimentation using physical lab equipment such as ballistic pucks, microscopes, beakers, and hot plates, combined with real-time measurement, analysis, and graphical content. Working with Tufts University and area educators, a new model of lab equipment has been demonstrated. The effective use of affordable technologies provides the access, supports, and scaffolds that students need to make sense of science and become excited by STEM (Science Technology Engineering and Math) creative opportunities. STEM-Table will be used in conjunction with traditional instruction, but leverage a wide range of new multimedia enhanced interactions, thereby transforming the STEM classroom into a more hands-on and responsive environment and elucidating the connections needed for fuller scientific understanding.

The broader/commercial impact is that (1) creating the classroom-ready, large-format, multi-touch STEM-Table brings unique, tangible interactive experiences to STEM Teaching Labs; (2) multi-touch STEM lab equipment enables a wide range of learning that combines data collection and hands-on lab skills with virtual media; and (3) the multi-touch environment will provide classrooms with a new paradigm for collaborative STEM activities with cost, capabilities, and workload reduction advantages. In the proposed work a fully-commercialized STEM Table "Multi-Science Augmented Reality Lab Bench" product will be deployed with associated tangible lab equipment surface devices. This technology will be classroom-tested and a user community will be supported with expanded applications. Based on the user and market reaction to the core technology evaluated to-date, this product will provide both a strong market position among current educational lab equipment and significant STEM education benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview – FTL Labs Corporation (FTL), of Amherst, MA, has completed a successful Phase II SBIR program with the National Science Foundation (NSF) to market robotic, augmented-reality, education, therapy and rehabilitation computer table products. FTL's technology has been feasibility tested with patients and students, demonstrated at CES in Las Vegas, raised $90k of related device development funding at UMass, and raised $75k through Kickstarter. FTL continues progressing this technology through develoment of specialized therapy/rehab applications for minimum viable product (MVP) testing at Baystate Medical Center and by expanding into control systems using emergy virtual reality (VR) systems like Oculus Rift.

Technology Platform – Tangible User Interfaces (TUIs) represent a paradigm for interacting with computers through objects and touch. This technology has great promise for quantifying and analyzing everyday physical motions of objects and for use as exercises in a clinical setting and as home therapy. Prior to the release of the first iPad in 2010, FTL proposed to the Navy that multitouch computers with object tracking capabilities could enable improved aircraft carrier logistics; challenges that had been addressed using plastic models and paper charts since World War II. FTL now designs, manufactures, and sells large-scale multitouch computer devices called “Playsurfaces”. Under NSF SBIR funding, FTL's object tracking technology has undergone hundreds of hours of testing in public and private settings, including research labs at UMass, with stroke rehabilitation patients, and in schools, as part of hands-on physics lessons. In partnership with FTL, UMass has developed the first mouse-like “surface robot” devices that greatly enhance the therapy and exercise value of the Playsurface platform. A dedicated development effort is required to bring FTL's approach to the clinical market, and UMass, Baystate Medical, and Cooley-Dickinson hospital are all interested in testing the technology with patients.

Innovation – FTL Labs continues to marked its Playsurface multitouch system to schools worldwide.  In addition, FTL, UMass-Amherst, and Cooley Dickinson Hospital are developing tangible, robotic surface devices for clinical use with large-format touch computing tables. Large-scale touch screen displays with haptic capabilities that can assist or resist user motion enable new types of therapies, games, and user experiences that cannot be obtained on smaller smart-phones and tablets, but avoid the power and complexity of most rehabilitative robotics approaches. Playsurface combines touch sensitivity, tracking of passive objects (such as a cup), and these “surface robots”, to enable graphically-driven exercises as part of upper extremity rehabilitation therapy. With this system, trusted upper-limb therapy approaches such as “reach and touch” and “crossing center-line” are modernized as real-time exercise-video-games suitable for independent use by patients of all ages, and apply built-in evaluation (such as Fugl-Meyer Assessment) and trending for tracking and reporting progress to caregivers. Additionally, through detailed motion tracking, scoring, and cloud archiving, the proposed approach enables emerging approaches for web tracking, telemedicine, and customizing therapies to individual patients. The build cost is low compared to most robotic systems (<$3k), enabling both medical providers and patients with disabilities to afford the system.
